standard-rules.title: Chess
standard-rules.quote: “The game of chess is a lake in which a mosquito can bathe and an elephant can drown.” – Indian Proverb

steps.text:
Chess is a modern, western variation of a type of board game that has been played for thousands of years. 
 Games of this family have a coordinate system as well as a set of movable figures, one of which is deemed important to the game's result.
This tutorial will not cover the basics of chess rules. If you are unfamiliar with chess, the free online platform lichess.org has a great comprehensive tutorial.
steps.note: The starting position for chess. Push the king pawn two squares forward to complete this exercise.

fairy-chess.title: Fairy Chess
fairy-chess.quote: “We do these things for ourselves alone.” – Thomas Dawson, fairy chess composer

steps.text:
“Fairy Chess“ is a general term for a chess variant that includes nonstandard piece types. 
 Below is a variant imagined by José Raúl Capablanca, a world chess champion. Note the unorthodox 10x8 board and the addition of two new piece types.

Variants such as Capablanca's chess were intended for full games, but it was also popular in some historical chess communities to invent new pieces for the sake of compositions (puzzles). Below is a 1911 puzzle by Thomas Dawson, a prolific composer of fairy chess problems. It involves a piece which combines the movement of a rook and a knight.
steps.note: White to move, mate in 2. Hint: you only need to move the special piece.

steps.text: Token Chess adds 8 fairy pieces and a draft system to the classic game. Each piece has a token cost, and players decide their own starting setup within a budget of 39 tokens.
steps.note: An example Token Chess starting position. There is no correct move here, the possibilities are endless!

Champion.title: Champion
Champion.quote: “Suffer now and live the rest of your life as a champion.” – Muhammad Ali

steps.text:
The Champion combines the movement of the Rook and Knight pieces. It is a classic addition in chess variants. 
 José Raúl Capablanca called it the “Chancellor,“ a popular name for the piece, but Token Chess refers to it by the name given by Italian priest Pietro Carrera, who first introduced the piece to western chess in the 17th century.
steps.note: Capture the pawn, then the knight.

steps.text: You can castle with the Champion, just as you would a rook!
steps.note: Castle with the Champion.

Princess.title: Princess
Princess.quote: “Your princess is quite a winning creature. Her appeal is undeniable.” – Rugen, The Princess Bride

steps.text: The Princess combines the movement of the Bishop and Knight. Like the Champion, it is a piece with a long history in chess variants. It is a deceptively strong piece that is quite difficult to play against-- in an open board, it is hard to escape even a lone princess.
steps.note: Find the checkmate in one.

Amazon.title: Amazon
Amazon.quote: “I will not be triumphed over.” – Cleopatra VII

steps.text: Behold! The all-powerful Queen+Knight combo, classically named the Amazon, after the greek mythological figures. Unlike any piece in standard chess, it can perform a checkmate without any additional help.
steps.note: Checkmate the enemy King in one move.

steps.text:
The Commoner is just like a King, but as it was not born into royalty, the game does not hinge on its well-being. 
 The Commoner is a strong defender, and it is most valuable in endgames. For example, despite having the same token cost as a Bishop or Knight, the Commoner can deliver checkmate with the help of the King.
steps.note: Checkmate the enemy King in two moves.

steps.text: There's more! If sufficiently close to your King, this little magician can effortlessly ward off a Queen, making a draw out of what *should* be a loss.
steps.note: Use the Commoner to block the checks.

Painter.title: Painter
Painter.quote: “I dream my paintings, and then I paint my dreams.” – Vincent van Gogh

steps.text: While similar to a pawn, the Painter has no violence in their heart. They are a dreamer and an artist, not a fighter. Rather than capture, the Painter paints enemy pieces to its own color.
steps.note: Push the painter, then paint the enemy Rook.

steps.text: Like a pawn, a Painter can capture en passant. But instead of capturing, the Painter paints the piece it passes (en paintssant).
steps.note: Push the painter, then paint en passant.

steps.text: The painter has a special promotion, meaning when it reaches the back rank it automatically promotes without choice by the player. The resulting piece is called the “Royal Painter“, which moves like a King but paints instead of capturing.
steps.note: Push the painter to promotion, then paint the rook with the Royal Painter.

Snare.title: Snare
Snare.quote: “It's a trap!” – Ackbar, Return of the Jedi

steps.text: The Snare is a piece that restricts the movement of enemy pieces within a certain range. The Snare can only move forward, and cannot capture.
steps.note: Push the Snare forward, then click black's pieces to see which ones can move.

steps.text:
One use for the Snare is forcing the exchange of a weaker piece for a strong one, also called “winning material.“ 
 It is generally a good idea to ensnare a valuable target that can easily be attacked, such as with a pawn.
steps.note: Ensnare the enemy Queen, then attack it with a pawn.

steps.text: Note that since the Snare cannot capture, it cannot give check. However, a King may be ensnared. In this case, the opposing side may deliver mate by simply giving a check.
steps.note: Ensnare the King, then deliver checkmate.

steps.text: Like the painter, the Snare has a special promotion. The superior piece, called the “Rolling Snare,“ has King movement with an additional square of movement in orthogonal directions. It also snares all 4 orthogonal directions, rather than the Snare's 3.
steps.note: Promote the Snare, catch the enemy King, then deliver checkmate.

steps.text: Click the Rolling Snare to see its full movement space, which resembles a diamond.
steps.note: Ensnare the King, then deliver checkmate.

Wizard.title: Wizard
Wizard.quote: “A wizard is never late. Nor is he early. He arrives precisely when he means to.” – Gandalf

steps.text: The Wizard moves up to two squares orthogonally. Like a Knight, the Wizard can jump over pieces.
steps.note: Jump over the pawn, then capture the bishop.

steps.text: The magic of the Wizard is its ability to swap places with a friendly piece within its movement range. This ability disregards pins, contrary to standard chess rules which disallow moving “through“ check.
steps.note: Escape the pin.

steps.text: The Wizard creates value by relocating poorly positioned pieces with low mobility. For example, a Wizard may create a passed pawn from an otherwise deadlocked structure.
steps.note: Use the wizard to create a passed pawn, then push the pawn.

steps.text: The Wizard may be used to escape the King from dangerous places, including positions which would otherwise be checkmate!
steps.note: Escape the checkmate attempt.

steps.text: While not a strong attacker, the Wizard is sufficient to deliver checkmate in an endgame.
steps.note: Use the Wizard to checkmate in three moves.

Archer.title: Archer
Archer.quote: “Swift as the wind, silent as the forest.” – Sun Tzu

steps.text: The Archer is a slow piece, moving one square diagonally at a time. This makes it a color-bound piece, like the Bishop.
steps.note: Capture the pawns.

steps.text: The Archer has the unique ability to capture without moving, given that the captured piece is 2 to 3 diagonal squares away.
steps.note: Capture the pieces in the following order: Knight, Rook, Pawn

token-values.title: Token Values
token-values.quote: “Tell me, how much a dollar cost?” – Kendrick Lamar

steps.text: Tokens give you budgeted points to spend on pieces. Use the Army Builder to create armies using the token budget.
In the Army Builder you can save and export armies as JSON so the Board Editor can place them.
